sen.j: 片岡 市太郎（かたおか いちたろう、1877年2月13日 - 没年不詳）は、日本の俳優である。
sen.e: Ichitaro KATAOKA (February 13, 1877 - date of death unknown) was a Japanese actor.
Ichitaro KATAOKA (February 13, 1877 - date of death unknown) was a Japanese actor.
Ichitaro KATAOKA (February 13, 1877 - date of death unknown) was a Japanese actor.

sen.j: 本名塚本 末吉（つかもと すえきち）。
sen.e: His real name was Suekichi TSUKAMOTO.
His real name was Suekichi TSUKAMOTO.
His real name was Suekichi TSUKAMOTO.

sen.j: 横田商会で映画製作を開始して以来の牧野省三を支えた、「マキノ」ブランド初期の主演俳優として知られる。
sen.e: He was known as a leading actor in the early "Makino" brand, supporting Shozo MAKINO since he started film making for Yokota Shokai (film studio).
He was known as a leading actor in the early "Makino" genre, supporting Shozo MAKINO since he started making films for the Yokota Shokai film studio.

He is known for his work as one of the leading men in several of the earliest films of director Shozo MAKINO's career; he started collaborating with Makino right from the beginning when Makino first began making films at the Yokota Shokai film studio.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: のちに元子役のマキノ登六が「片岡市太郎」を名乗るが、33歳も年齢が違う別人である。
sen.e: Toroku MAKINO, who was a child actor, later called himself "Ichitaro KATAOKA," but he was a person different from Ichitaro KATAOKA as he was younger than Ichitaro KATAOKA as much as 33 years.
Toroku MAKINO, who had been a child actor, later called himself "Ichitaro KATAOKA," but he was different from Ichitaro KATAOKA and, in fact, was as much as 33 years younger than Ichitaro KATAOKA.

In later years, a child actor named Toroku MAKINO also took the stage name "Ichitaro KATAOKA," but he--fully 33 years younger than the Kataoka under discussion here--was clearly a different person entirely.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 1877年（明治10年）2月13日、京都市堺町通丸太町通（のちに上京区の同所）に、目の前にある京都御所専門の彫刻師・原沢彦右衛門の子として生まれる。
sen.e: On February 13, 1877, he was born as a son of Hikoemon HARASAWA, who was a captive sculptor of Kyoto Imperial Palace located in front of his house on Sakaimachi-dori Street, Marutamachi-dori Street (present-day Kamigyo Ward, the same streets) in Kyoto City.

On February 13, 1877, he was born as the son of Hikoemon HARASAWA, who was a captive sculptor of Kyoto Imperial Palace, which was located in front of his house on Sakaimachi-dori Street, Marutamachi-dori Street (the same streets of the present-day Kamigyo Ward) in Kyoto City.

Kataoka was born on February 13, 1877 to Hikoemon HARASAWA, the master sculptor for Kyoto Imperial Palace, at Harasawa's house on the corner of Sakaimachi-dori and Marutamachi-dori streets, right across from the Imperial Palace.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 1881年（明治14年）に父が死去、塚本清三郎の養子となる。
sen.e: His father died in 1881 and he was adopted by Seizaburo TSUKAMOTO.
His father died in 1881, and subsequently he was adopted by Seizaburo TSUKAMOTO.
Upon his father's death in 1881, he was adopted by Seizaburo TSUKAMOTO.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 大谷友松一座の片岡市蔵に弟子入りし、「片岡市太郎」を名乗って京都「真砂座」初舞台を踏む。
sen.e: He was apprenticed to Ichizo KATAOKA in the troupe led by Tomomatsu OTANI and called himself "Ichitaro KATAOKA" to make a debut in "Masagoza" (theater) in Kyoto.
He was apprenticed to Ichizo KATAOKA in the troupe led by Tomomatsu OTANI, and called himself "Ichitaro KATAOKA" as he debuted in the "Masagoza" (theater) of Kyoto.

He began an apprenticeship under Ichizo KATAOKA, a member of the acting troupe led by Tomomatsu OTANI, and first debuted on stage under the stage name 'Ichitaro KATAOKA' at the Masagoza Theater in Kyoto.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 養父とともに各地を巡業、学校教育は受けられなかった。
sen.e: He went on a tour with his adoptive father across the country, so he could not have schooling.
He went on tour with his adoptive father across the country, so he couldn't have formal schooling.
Because he was always on tour around the country with his adoptive father, he never received any formal education.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 1894年（明治27年）、17歳で京都「岩上座」に立つ。
sen.e: In 1894, he made his stage debut in "Iwagamiza" (theater) at age 17.
In 1894, at 17 years of age, he made his stage debut in the "Iwagamiza" (theater).
In 1894, when he was 17, Ichitaro made his stage debut at the Iwagamiza Theater
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: そののちに名古屋の市川新四郎一座に参加、立女形となる。
sen.e: After that, he participated in the troupe led by Shinshiro ICHIKAWA in Nagoya and became tateoyama (the leading Onnagata actor).
After that, he participated in the troupe led by Shinshiro ICHIKAWA in Nagoya and became tateoyama (the leading Onnagata actor).
Thereafter, he joined Shinshiro ICHIKAWA's acting troupe in Nagoya and became their leading Onnagata actor (a male actor who plays women's roles).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 同一座が京都「千本座」を常打ち小屋としたときに、当時同劇場の経営者だった1歳下の牧野省三と出逢う。
sen.e: When the troupe decided to have regular performances at "Senbonza" (theater) in Kyoto, he met Shozo MAKINO, who was an owner of the theater and one year younger than him.
When the troupe decided to have regular performances at "Senbonza" (theater) in Kyoto, he met Shozo MAKINO, who was an owner of the theater and one year younger than him.
He met Shozo MAKINO, a theater owner who was one year younger than him, around the time the Ichikawa troupe started to hold regular performances at the Senbonza Theater in Kyoto.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 1908年（明治41年）に牧野が横田永之助の横田商会に依頼され、サイレント映画『本能寺合戦』を初めて監督。
sen.e: In 1908, upon the request by Yokota Shokai that was run by Einosuke YOKOTA, Makino directed a silent movie "Honnoji Kassen" (Battle of Honnoji) for the first time.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 1908, upon the request from Yokota Shokai, which was run by Einosuke YOKOTA, Makino made his cinematic directorial debut with the (silent) film "Honnoji Kassen (Battle of Honnoji)."
In 1908, Makino was commissioned by the Yokota Shokai film studio, run by Einosuke YOKOTA, to direct his first film, the (silent) "Honnoji Kassen" (The Battle at Honnoji Temple).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 9月17日に公開されるが、ここから始まる一連の牧野監督作に市川新四郎一座で出演している。
sen.e: The film was released on September 17, which was the first one in a series of films directed by Makino where Ichitaro appeared in the troupe led by Shinshiro ICHIKAWA.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The film, released on September 17, was the first in a series of films directed by Makino in which Ichitaro participated as part of the troupe led by Shinshiro ICHIKAWA.
This film, released on September 17, turned out to be the first of a series of films directed by Makino in which Ichitaro as one member of the Shinshiro ICHIKAWA acting troupe, would appear.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 1909年（明治42年）10月、牧野が岡山の金光教本部を参詣したときに発見した尾上松之助を主演に据えた本格的な映画製作を開始するが、その第1作『碁盤忠信 源氏礎』に市太郎は「源義経」役で出演する。
sen.e: In October 1909, Makino fully started film making, putting Matsunosuke ONOE in a leading actor, who Makino met when he visited the Konkokyo Headquarters in Okayama; however, Ichitaro appeared in the first film "Goban Tadanobu Genji no Ishizue," playing the role of 'MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune.'

In October 1909, Makino went into film-making on a full-scale basis; his lead actor was Matsunosuke ONOE, whom Makino had met during a visit to the Konkokyo headquarters in Okayama; however, Ichitaro appeared in the first film "Goban Tadanobu Genji no Ishizue," playing the role of 'MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune.'

After a visit in October 1909 to the Konkokyo headquarters in Okayama during which he had discovered Matsunosuke ONOE's talent and recruited him as his new leading man, Makino devoted himself entirely to filmmaking; Ichitaro appeared in Makino's first post-1909 film, "Goban Tadanobu Genji no Ishizue," playing the role of MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 同作以降、市太郎は舞台を廃業し「映画俳優」となる。
sen.e: After the appearance in that film, Ichitaro gave up the stage and became a "film actor."
After the appearance in that film, Ichitaro left the stage to become a "film actor."
After his appearance in that film, Ichitaro ended his stage acting career and became a film actor.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 横田商会、1912年（大正元年）の同社の合併による日活の設立、1919年（大正8年）の牧野の日活からの独立によるミカド商会の設立、そして牧野の日活への復帰、と牧野省三の行動に、市太郎は完全に同行する。
sen.e: Ichitaro fully accompanied Shozo MAKINO: in Yokota Shokai, Nikkatsu Corporation established by the merger of Yokota Shokai etc. in 1912, Mikado Shokai (film studio) established by Makino to be independent of the Nikkatsu Corporation in 1919, and the Makino's return to the Nikkatsu Corporation.

Ichitaro fully accompanied Shozo MAKINO in Yokota Shokai; however, the Nikkatsu Corporation was established by the merger of Yokota Shokai, etc., in 1912, and the Mikado Shokai film studio was established by Makino independently of the Nikkatsu Corporation in 1919, but eventually Makino returned to the Nikkatsu Corporation.

Ichitaro's allegiance to Shozo MAKINO never swayed throughout Makino's career, working with Makino when the latter was employed by Yokota Shokai, and staying with Makino after Yokota Shokai was merged in 1912 to form Nikkatsu Corporation; Ichitaro followed Makino when he established the Mikado Shokai film studio to win his independence from Nikkatsu Corporation in 1919, and followed him back when he subsequently returned to Nikkatsu Corporation.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: この間、市太郎は牧野の異父妹・牧野京子と結婚し、マキノ家の一員となる。
sen.e: During this period, Ichitaro married Kyoko MAKINO, who was a half sister of Makino, and became a member of the Makino family.
During this period, Ichitaro married Kyoko MAKINO, who was a half-sister of Makino, and became a member of the Makino family.
During these transitional years, Ichitaro married Makino's half-sister Kyoko MAKINO, thus becoming a member of the Makino family.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: ミカド商会設立第1作、金森万象監督の『都に憧れて』では牧野京子と共演している。
sen.e: He acted with Kyoko MAKINO in "Miyako ni Akogarete" (longing for the city) (directed by Bansho KANAMORI), the first film made by Mikado Shokai.
He acted with Kyoko MAKINO in "Miyako ni Akogarete (Longing for the City)," directed by Bansho KANAMORI as the first film produced by Mikado Shokai.
He and Kyoko MAKINO both appeared in the first film produced by Mikado Shokai, "Miyako ni Akogarete" (Longing for the Capital), which was directed by Bansho KANAMORI.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 1921年（大正10年）6月、牧野省三が再度日活から独立、等持院撮影所を建設し、牧野教育映画製作所を設立、さらには1923年（大正12年）の同社のマキノ映画製作所を設立。
sen.e: In June 1921, Shozo MAKINO became independent of the Nikkatsu Corporation again and built Tojiin Studio, established Makino Kyoiku Eiga Seisakujo (film studio), and then Makino Eiga Seisakujo (film studio) of the same company in 1923.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In June 1921, Shozo MAKINO became independent of the Nikkatsu Corporation again; he built Tojiin Studio, established the Makino Kyoiku Eiga Seisakujo film studio and then the Makino Eiga Seisakujo film studio under the same company in 1923.

In June 1921, Shozo MAKINO again broke away from Nikkatsu Corporation and went independent, establishing both the Tojiin Studio and the Makino Kyoiku Eiga Seisakujo film studio and then combining those two studios into the Makino Eiga Seisakujo film studio, which he founded in 1923.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: これらの発展的な改称・改組にあたっても市川幡谷とともに「マキノ」の初期を支えた。
sen.e: Throughout such developments with renaming and reorganization, Ichitaro supported the early "Makino" together with Hataya ICHIKAWA.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Throughout such developments with renaming and reorganization, Ichitaro supported the early "Makino" together with Hataya ICHIKAWA.
Yet through all the renamings and reorganizations, Ichitaro and Hataya ICHIKAWA both continued to give Makino their unstinting support throughout his early career.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 同年秋には新スター阪東妻三郎が登場、二川文太郎、井上金太郎といった20世紀生まれの20代前半の監督が登場するにあたり、次第に脇にシフト、47歳を迎える1924年（大正13年）の沼田紅緑監督の『燃ゆる渦巻』での環歌子との共演あたりが最後の主役となる。
sen.e: In the fall, the same year, a new star Tsumasaburo BANDO came out and directors Buntaro FUTAGAWA and Kintaro INOUE, who were born in the 20th century and early 20s, appeared; accordingly, Ichitaro gradually shifted to a supporting actor and played the last leading part, acting with Utako TAMAKI, in 1924 at the age of 47 in "Moyuru Uzumaki" (burning spiral) directed by Koroku NUMATA.

In the fall of the same year a new star named Tsumasaburo BANDO emerged, and directors Buntaro FUTAGAWA and Kintaro INOUE, who were born in the twentieth century and early 1920s, appeared; accordingly, Ichitaro gradually shifted to the role of a supporting actor and, in 1924 at age 47, he played his last leading part, acting alongside Utako TAMAKI in "Moyuru Uzumaki (Burning Spiral)," directed by Koroku NUMATA.

The fall of 1923 saw the emergence of a new film star, Tsumasaburo BANDO, as well as young new directors Buntaro FUTAGAWA and Kintaro INOUE, both born in the twentieth century and thus still in their early twenties; consequently, Ichitaro was more and more often given roles as supporting actor, and his last leading role, acting alongside Utako TAMAKI, was in "Moyuru Uzumaki" (Burning Spiral), directed by Koroku NUMATA, which was made in 1924 when Ichitaro was forty-seven.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: やがて姿を消した。
sen.e: Consequently, he retired as actor.
Consequently, he retired from acting.
Consequently, he retired from acting.
